title: 106_s630
content: TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THE FLATHEAD IRRIGATION PROJECT, MONTANA. The purpose of this Act is to preserve family farms and ranches in Montana by transferring responsibility for the Flathead Irrigation Project without affecting water rights negotiations. Definitions include "contract" and "irrigation district." The Act defines key terms such as "irrigation district," "project," "Secretary," and "Tribe" in relation to the Flathead Irrigation Project on the Flathead Indian Reservation in Montana. The Act defines key terms related to the Flathead Irrigation Project, including the Secretary as the Secretary of the Interior and the Tribe as the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes. The Secretary is required to offer a contract to the irrigation district within a year for project management. The Secretary must offer a contract to the irrigation district for project management, including all rights and powers. The contract must identify trust responsibilities to the Tribe and ensure the United States can fulfill them. The United States must ensure that the irrigation district maintains instream flows set by the Bureau of Indian Affairs to protect fisheries. Existing obligations for project construction costs repayment must continue. The United States must ensure that the irrigation district maintains instream flows set by the Bureau of Indian Affairs to protect fisheries. Obligations for project construction costs repayment must continue unaffected by this Act, with provisions for an accelerated payment option and amendments to repayment contracts for net revenues from the Power Division operation. The United States must ensure that the irrigation district maintains instream flows set by the Bureau of Indian Affairs to protect fisheries. Repayment contracts between the irrigation district and the United States need to be amended to separate net revenues from the Power Division for operation and maintenance costs of the Irrigation Division. The contract may be revoked if the irrigation district damages tribal trust assets knowingly and willingly. The irrigation district must operate the project in a way that does not damage tribal trust assets. The project's operation should follow the Bureau of Indian Affairs plan of operations from October 31, 1997, to protect these assets. Any changes in operation must be made based on new information or administrative policies. The irrigation district must operate the project to protect tribal trust assets as per the Bureau of Indian Affairs plan of operations from October 31, 1997. Changes in operation must be based on new information or administrative policies, and negotiations with the district should start promptly. The Secretary must negotiate with the irrigation district promptly to transfer ownership of equipment and supplies paid for with operation and maintenance funds related to the project. The Secretary will transfer ownership of equipment and supplies purchased with operation and maintenance funds to the irrigation district, excluding real property rights and water rights. This Act does not impact water rights negotiations between the State of Montana, the United States, and the Tribe.
